blocks.text:
Then

H = internal + external energy

i.e.,

H = T - P V

where H is the enthalpy. Then,

H = (PV) - (PAV + PBV)

From Example 1, replacing y by the constant gas laws:

T = 1028.3°F, 

hence we want to raise the temperature t:

t = T - 32

Now the specific heat to raise the temperature t:

c = T - H

and hence

if  $y$ is greater than 305, $i$ is a negative quantity.

E.g., if:

2y = 2C - 305 - 305 + 76'F = 767°F.

$E.g.:$ i = 305 - 345 - 88.

blocks.title: Work Done in the Expansion of a Gas.

blocks.text:
Example 3 - Find the work done in the expansion of a gas from volume $V_1$ to volume $V_2$. 

There are two distinct cases, which must be treated separately; but for both cases the volume done in the expansion is measured by the area ABCD = areas of strips like MN (Fig. 1).

blocks.caption: Figure 1: Work Done in Gas Expansion.
blocks.description: This figure illustrates the work done during the expansion of a gas, represented by the shaded area under the curve in a volume-pressure diagram.

blocks.text:
Case (a), for which the law of the expansion is $p = C$. 

Work done = $W =  rac{p}{ho} = C \log \frac{V_2}{V_1}$. 

Thus the work done = $p \log \frac{V_2}{V_1}$.

blocks.description: This equation represents the work done during the expansion of a gas, where $p$ is the pressure and the logarithm term accounts for the volume change.
